description: Clipping of grotesque  +‎ -y. Doublet of grody, the American equivalent. Compare Middle English groti, grooti (“slimy, muddy”), from Old English grotiġ (“earthy, dirty”) (modern dialectal English groaty, Scots grotty), which is equivalent to groat +‎ -y. Compare also Scottish Gaelic grod (“rotten, lousy, terrible”), Middle Irish grot (“bitter, sour”).
Originated or popularised by the 1964 film A Hard Day's Night, starring the Beatles and written by Alun Owen.

entries.meaning: (slang, Britain, Canada, Australia, New Zealand) Unpleasant, dirty, slovenly or offensive.
examples: George: I wouldn't be seen dead in them. They're dead grotty.

adjectives.description: grotty (comparative grottier or more grotty, superlative grottiest or most grotty)
